title: Would it be possible for a device in the future that sends electrical signals to the brain in order to 'upload' information to it be possible? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think it that exact thing would be very difficult. The problem is that long term “knowledge” is encapsulated in the wiring of the brain. It’s not “software” it’s “wiring”. The only “software” memory we have is short-term. It self erases after maybe 10 to 20 minutes…just enough time for the long term storage system to rewire some neurons. So anything we wanted to insert into the brain permanently would have to be inserted at the same glacial speeds we can go at when we read something in a book or whatever. SO WHAT IS (POTENTIALLY) POSSIBLE? What I think is more plausible is attaching some piece of electronic circuitry (containing “information”) to the brain and teaching the brain to use it. It’s hard to imagine what that might be like you. WHAT I’M NOT THINKING OF: What I’m not really thinking of is something like you sub-vocalizing the words “Hey Google: What is the albedo of the moon?” …and then hearing (but not through your ears) - “About zero point one two”. That would just be fractionally faster than just saying it into your phone…not really much of an advance at all. WHAT I AM THINKING OF: I’m thinking more of a kind of thing where you’re trying to think of the albedo of the moon…and you don’t quite have it - it’s on the tip of your tongue…and then you remember it. It pops into your head, just like any other memory. So rather than the kind of “instant learning” thing you saw in The Matrix when Trinity needs to know how to fly a helicopter - and it’s pushed into her brain cells…but also not like using Siri or Alexa. The memories lie outside your brain - but the access method makes it seem like you already knew it. BESIDES - JUST INSERTING MEMORIES ISN’T ENOUGH: I’d really like a calculator in my head…so just like I can think “three times five” and “fifteen” pops into my head - I could think “twelve point six five divided by nine point two” and the answer to that pops into my head. It would be nice to have a spell-checker that watches what I’m about to type and just corrects it on the way to my fingers. For a large class of things - just think about doing something without needing to actually do it…imagine I could reach out a long, stretchy arm to turn on a light switch 10 feet away - and have the computer turn on the light for me.

I believe it will be simpler and more complex. We will have small, rice grain sized, computer implanted in our skull. There will be a brain interface. There will be AI on board. The data will be uploaded into the computer. The interface will give you access to the data. Best of luck.
